DataRchive

Believe in God

Author

Ashmita Biswas

Believe in God

Real or Myth?

About the Data

This data set explores the spiritual landscape of art students. A quantitative analysis of divine belief patterns at Srishti Manipal Institute.

Data Dictionary

Qualitative Variables

Name: Name of the student

Gender: Gender of the student, categorized by ‘Male’ and ‘Female’

Believe_in_God: Students’ believe in God, categorized as ‘Yes’ and ‘No’

Hypothesis

  • In an art & design educational environment, will students show higher rates of non-belief compared to the general population due to exposure to diverse perspectives and critical thinking emphasis?

Something more to look for

  • There might be gender differences in religious belief patterns due potential cultural socialization influences.

Checking for missing data

believe_data %>%
  visdat::vis_miss()
believe_data %>%
  visdat::vis_dat()

There are missing values in the data as some students might have chose to not answer the question. Hence removing unanswered entries.

believe_mod1 <- believe_data %>% 
  naniar::replace_with_na_all(condition = ~ .x %in% common_na_strings) %>% 
drop_na()

Munging the Data

Factoring ‘gender’ and ‘believe_in_god’

believe_mod2 <- believe_mod1 %>% 
mutate(gender = as.factor(gender),
       believe_in_god = as.factor(believe_in_god))

Counting gender

believe_mod2 %>% 
  dplyr::count(gender) %>%
  tt()
gender n
Female 23
Male 18 
believe_mod2 %>%
  gf_bar(~gender, fill = "gold") %>%
  gf_labs(
    title = "Gender representation",
    x = "Gender",
    y = "Count"
  )

Observation

  • There is a slight imbalance in the gender proportion, but not very significant.

  • Both genders have substantial representation, though not perfectly equal

Counting believe_in_god

believe_mod2 %>% 
  dplyr::count(believe_in_god) %>%
  tt()
believe_in_god n
No 15
Yes 26 
believe_mod2 %>% 
gf_bar(~believe_in_god, fill = "orange") %>% 
gf_labs(title = "Do students believe in God?",
       x = "Believes in God",
       y = "Count")

Observation

  • Clearly, majority believe in God vs. not believing.

  • Believers outnumber non-believers by nearly 2 to 1

  • The sample has a slight female majority - could this gender imbalance influence the overall belief distribution?

Belief by Gender

Counting Belief by Gender

believe_mod2 %>% 
    count(across(c("gender", "believe_in_god"))) %>%
  tt()
gender believe_in_god n
Female No 5
Female Yes 18
Male No 10
Male Yes 8

Visualizing in a Dodged Bar graph

believe_mod2 %>%
  gf_bar(~believe_in_god, fill = ~gender, position = "dodge") %>%
  gf_labs(
    title = "Belief in God by Gender",
    x = "Believes in God",
    y = "Count",
    fill = "Gender"
  )

Observation

  • There is a strong belief among females where, 18 are believer and 6 are non-believers
  • For males, the belief in nearly split where, 8 are believers and 9 arenon-believers
  • Gender seems to be a predictor of religious belief in this student population, with female students nearly twice as likely to believe in God compared to male students.

Checking the correlation between Gender and Belief with Mosaic Plot

vcd::structable(gender ~ believe_in_god, data = believe_mod2) %>%
  vcd::mosaic(shade = TRUE, legend = TRUE,
              main = "Gender vs Belief in God",
              gp = shading_max)

Observation:

  • Since p < 0.05, there is statistically significant evidence that gender affects belief in God patterns among students

  • Although it is important to note that, p = 0.044 is barely significant (close to the 0.05 threshold) and the relation might be fairly weak.

  • With a smaller sample, this small of a difference might not be significant

Conclusion from EDA

This analysis reveals two key insights about religious belief among art & design students:

1. Majority maintains traditional belief

  • Contrary to the hypothesis, 65% of the students believe in God, a substantial majority that challenges expectations of higher secularism in creative educational environments.

2. Significant gender divide

  • A pronounced gender gap exists: 18 female students believe versus only 8 of males - a difference that is statistically significant (p = 0.044), though the relationship is relatively weak.

Inference

Null hypothesis: TThe proportion of students who believe in God is 50% - there is no majority preference in either direction.

Statically, H₀: p = 0.5

Performing Binom Test

mosaic::binom.test(~believe_in_god, data = believe_mod2, success = "Yes")



data:  believe_mod2$believe_in_god  [with success = Yes]
number of successes = 26, number of trials = 41, p-value = 0.1173
alternative hypothesis: true probability of success is not equal to 0.5
95 percent confidence interval:
 0.4693625 0.7787721
sample estimates:
probability of success 
             0.6341463 
mosaic::binom.test(~believe_in_god, data = believe_mod2, success = "Yes") %>%
  broom::tidy()
# A tibble: 1 × 7
  estimate statistic p.value parameter conf.low conf.high alternative
     <dbl>     <dbl>   <dbl>     <dbl>    <dbl>     <dbl> <chr>      
1    0.634        26   0.117        41    0.469     0.779 two.sided

Key Findings

  • The p-value (0.117) indicates we cannot reject the null hypothesis that belief and non-belief are equally distributed (50–50).
  • Observed Belief rate: 63.4% of art students believe in God
  • Not significant at the 0.05 level (p = 0.117).
  • The true population proportion likely falls between 47% and 78%

Although a numerical majority (63%) identify as believers, the difference is not statistically significant, suggesting that this imbalance could occur by chance in a population with equal proportions of belief and non-belief.

Final interpretation

Art & Design students do not show a statistically significant tendency toward belief or non-belief in God. While the 63% belief rate hints at a potential leaning toward theism, the evidence is insufficient to conclude a meaningful departure from an even 50–50 distribution.
